column1: Aylesbury ( AYLZ-bər-ee) is the county town of Buckinghamshire
column2: South East England. It is a large ancient market town with several historic pubs
column3: is home to the Roald Dahl Children's Gallery and
column4: since 2010
column5: the 1
column6: 200 seat Waterside Theatre. The town is recognized as the spiritual cradle of the Paralympic Games. It is situated in central Buckinghamshire
column7: midway between High Wycombe and Milton Keynes.

column1: Aylesbury was awarded Garden Town status by the Government on 2 January 2017. The town's housing is set to grow by over 16
column2: 000 homes by 2033 in Vale of Aylesbury Local Plan.

column1: The town name is of Old English origin.  Its first recorded name Æglesburgh is thought to mean "Fort of Ægel"
column2: though who Ægel was is not recorded. It is also possible that Ægeles-burh
column4: means "church-burgh"
column5: from the Welsh word eglwys meaning "a church" (<Latin ecclesia).Excavations in the town centre in 1985 found an Iron Age hill fort dating from the early 4th century BC.  Aylesbury was one of the strongholds of the ancient Britons
column6: from whom it was taken in the year 571 by Cutwulph
column8: King of the West Saxons; and had a fortress or castle "of some importance
column9: from which circumstance probably it derives its Saxon appellation".Aylesbury was a major market town in Anglo-Saxon times
column10: the burial place of Saint Osgyth
column11: whose shrine attracted pilgrims.  The Early English parish church of St. Mary (which has many later additions) has a crypt beneath.  Once thought to be Anglo-Saxon
column12: it is now recognised as being of the same period as the medieval chapel above. At the Norman conquest
column13: the king took the manor of Aylesbury for himself
column14: and it is listed as a royal manor in the Domesday Book
column15: 1086.  Some lands here were granted by William the Conqueror to citizens upon the tenure that the owners should provide straw for the monarch's bed
column16: sweet herbs for his chamber and two green geese and three eels for his table

column2: a religious institution called the Guild of St Mary was founded in Aylesbury by John Kemp
column3: Archbishop of York.  Known popularly as the Guild of Our Lady it became a meeting place for local dignitaries and a hotbed of political intrigue. The guild was influential in the final outcome of the Wars of the Roses. Its premises at the Chantry in Church Street
column4: Aylesbury
column5: are still there
column6: though today the site is used mainly for retail.

column1: Aylesbury was declared the new county town of Buckinghamshire in 1529 by King Henry VIII: Aylesbury Manor was among the many properties belonging to Thomas Boleyn
column2: the father of Anne Boleyn
column3: and it is rumoured that the change was made by the King to curry favour with the family. The plague decimated the population in 1603/4.

column1: The town played a large part in the English Civil War when it became a stronghold for the Parliamentarian forces
column2: like many market towns a nursing-ground of Puritan sentiment and in 1642 the Battle of Aylesbury was fought and won by the Parliamentarians.  Its proximity to Great Hampden
column3: home of John Hampden has made of Hampden a local hero: his silhouette is on the emblem used by Aylesbury Vale District Council and his statue stands prominently in the town centre.  Aylesbury-born composer
column4: Rutland Boughton (1878–1960)
column5: possibly inspired by the statue of John Hampden
column6: created a symphony based on Oliver Cromwell.

column2: Robert Bruce
column3: 2nd Earl of Elgin in the Peerage of Scotland was created 1st Earl of AilesburyThe grade II* listed Jacobean mansion of Hartwell adjoining the southwest of the town was the residence of Louis XVIII during his exile (1810–1814).  Bourbon Street in Aylesbury is named after the king.  Louis's wife
column4: Marie Josephine of Savoy died at Hartwell in 1810 and is the only French queen to have died on English soil. After her death
column5: her body was carried first to Westminster Abbey
column6: and one year later to Sardinia
column7: where the Savoy King of Sardinia had withdrawn during Napoleonic occupation of Turin and Piedmont; she is buried in the Cathedral of Cagliari.

column1: Aylebury's heraldic crest displays the Aylesbury duck
column2: which has been bred here since the birth of the Industrial Revolution
column4: Richard Waller
column5: of true Aylesbury ducks remains today.The town also received international publicity in the 1963 when the culprits responsible for the Great Train Robbery (1963) were tried at Aylesbury Rural District Council Offices in Walton Street and sentenced at Aylesbury Crown Court.  The robbery took place at Bridego Bridge
column6: a railway bridge at Ledburn
column7: about six miles (10 km) from the town.

column1: A notable institution is Aylesbury Grammar School which was founded in 1598.  The original building is now part of the County Museum buildings in Church Street and has grade II* architecture; other grammar schools now include Sir Henry Floyd Grammar School and Aylesbury High School.  Other notable buildings are the King's Head Inn
column2: (which with the Fleece Inn at Bretforton
column3: is one of the few public houses in the country owned by the National Trust still run as a public house) and the Queens Park Centre.

column2: canal
column4: Aylesbury Gaol
column5: the King's Head Inn and views of the town during the 1940s and 1950s
column6: examples of which can be seen in the Buckinghamshire County Museum in Aylesbury.

column1: The town's population has grown from 28
column2: 000 in the 1960s to almost 72
column3: 000 in 2011 due in the main to new housing developments
column4: including many London overspill housing estates
column5: built to ease pressure on the capital
column6: and to move people from crowded inner city slums to more favourable locations. Indeed
column8: to a greater extent than many English market towns
column9: saw substantial areas of its own heart demolished in the 1950s/1960s as 16th–18th century houses (many in good repair) were demolished to make way for new
column11: development.Aylesbury's population in the ten-year period since 2001 has grown by two thousand primarily related to the development of new housing estates which will eventually cater for eight thousand people on the north side
column12: between the A41 (Akeman Street) and the A413 and the expansion of Fairford Leys estate.

column2: soil and geology ===

column1: Aylesbury is immediately southeast of the upper River Thame that flows past Thame to Dorchester on Thames and is partly sited on the two northernmost outcrops of Portland (lime)stone in England bisected by a small stream
column2: Bear Brook which gives a relatively prominent position in relation to the terrain of all near
column4: fields and suburbs
column5: which have largely slowly permeable Oxford Clay and Kimmeridge Clay soils. Elevations range from 72.5m above mean sea level to 95m AOD in contiguous parts of the town
column6: however nearest villages range from 85m-90m to the north or from 85m to 115m on a narrow ridge to the southwest at Stone and towards the Chilterns to the southeast (Weston Turville
column7: Stoke Mandeville and North Lee).The town centre's higher terrain is accurately described by Samuel Lewis in 1848 as a "gentle eminence".

column1: The county's oldest rocks of Jurassic age cover the whole of the northern half of Buckinghamshire
column2: succeeded continuously by younger rocks to the south of the Chilterns.

column1: The town centre has many pubs and bars and the Queens Park Centre
column2: the UK's largest independent arts centre.The local newspaper is the Bucks Herald
column3: which started publishing in January 1832. The local radio station is Mix 96
column4: which first broadcast in April 1994.

column1: One of the more prominent buildings in Aylesbury is the "Blue Leanie" office block
column2: home to Lloyds Bank. When first built it was thought to be a potential hazard to passing motorists
column3: due to the sun reflecting off its large mirrored surface. As a result
column4: a line of mature trees was planted alongside the main road to prevent dazzling.Aylesbury Waterside Theatre
column5: a new £42 million theatre
column6: with 1

column9: the surrounding area is being redeveloped as part of the £100 million Waterside project. When this is completed
column13: 000 m2) of new retail floor space and 1
column15: although when this will be completed now is unclear. A Waitrose supermarket opened opposite the theatre in August 2013
column16: along with a Travelodge Hotel. Branches of Wagamama and Nando's restaurants opened on 'The Exchange' in February 2014
column17: next to the Odeon cinema on Exchange Street. A branch of Zizzi is also expected to open in early 2015
column18: as part of a council plan to revitalise the 'Waterside' area. The Zizzi opening turned out to be a rumour and in fact a Gourmet Burger Kitchen (GBK) opened instead.The Bourg Walk Bridge (also called the Southcourt Bridge or the Roberts Bridge after a local councillor) opened in March 2009 connecting Southcourt to Aylesbury town centre. The focus of the footbridge is a central concrete pillar with four suspension cables supporting the structure. This bridge forms a central part of the Aylesbury Hub project. Bourg Walk was nominated and won the Engineering Excellence Award 2009 awarded by the Institution of Civil Engineers – South East England branch .

column1: Aylesbury Town Council is the parish council within Aylesbury Vale district for the town. In 2012 it comprises 25 councillors
column2: 15 of whom are Liberal Democrats
column4: 2 UKIP and 1 Labour. The council represents only the constituents of Aylesbury town itself. Surrounding villages and some recent developments on the outskirts of Aylesbury like Fairford Leys & Watermead have their own parish council. In 2010 the district council decided that the new developments of Berryfields and Weedon Hill
column5: both to the north of Aylesbury
column6: should also join to form a new parish as of May 2011.The Town Council also elects the Town Mayor from the serving Town Councillors every year. The process culminates in a formal "Mayor Making" ceremony where the new Mayor takes over from the preceding Mayor. The role of mayor is mainly a ceremonial role representing the town at various events and acting as an ambassador for the town – the organisation is also in a process of discussions to take over responsibility for some public services from Aylesbury Vale District.

column2: three grammar schools
column4: an academy

column1: Aylesbury Music Centre is a large educational establishment
column2: which has its own premises adjoining Aylesbury High School and rivals the Royal College of Music

column1: Stoke Mandeville Hospital is a large National Health Service hospital to the south of the town centre. Its National Spinal Injuries Centre is one of the largest specialist spinal units in the world
column2: and the pioneering rehabilitation work carried out there by Sir Ludwig Guttmann led to the development of the Paralympic Games. Stoke Mandeville Stadium was developed alongside the hospital and is the National Centre for Disability Sport in the United Kingdom.Royal Buckinghamshire Hospital is a private hospital specialising in spinal cord injury.Aylesbury has for mental health therapy and treatments the Tindal Centre on Bierton Road. The Tindal Centre closed in early 2014 and Mental Health therapy and treatments along with Adult and Older Adult Mental Health Team's moved across the road to the new purpose built hospital the Whiteleaf Centre. The former site of Tindal Centre has been transformed into a new housing development Bierton Place which has maintained the architecture of the original building and enhanced its beauty

column1: Traditionally the town was a commercial centre with a market dating back to the Saxon period. This is because it was established on the main Akeman Street which became an established trade route linking London to the southwest. In 1180 a gaol was established in the town .

By 1477 flour was being ground in the town for surrounding parishes. By the modern period this had grown into a huge established industry: the last mill in Aylesbury was closed in the 1990s (Hills & Partridge on the canal behind Tesco). By 1560 the manufacture of needles had become a large industry in Long Crendon a village close by which was an important production centre.

In 1672 poor children in Buckinghamshire were taught to make lace as a way to make a living. Bucks lace as it became known quickly became very sought after and production boomed as the lace was mainly made by poor women and children. The lace-making industry had died out by Victorian times
column2: however
column3: as new machine-made lace became preferable.

column1: In 1764 Euclid Neale opened his clockmaking workshop in Aylesbury. In the 18th century
column2: he was one of the best clock makers in the country.
the Aylesbury arm of the Grand Union Canal from Marsworth was opened bringing major industry to the town for the first time. At the same time the Wendover arm was built leading to nearby Wendover.

column1: From 1919 until 1925 the Cubit Engineering Works on Bicester Road was a volume manufacturer of motor vehicles. Approximately 3
column2: 000 cars were built
column3: but a somewhat slow and heavy design could not survive the onslaught from cheap American competition. The works have been demolished for a domestic housing development. The marque is commemorated by Cubitt Street (and Edge Street) which traverses the old works.

column2: the printers and bookbinders
column4: Watson and Viney and the Nestlé dairy were the two main employers in the town
column5: employing more than half the total population. These factories have long since been demolished and replaced by a Tesco supermarket which opened in 1994
column6: and a housing development

column2: the town is still a major commercial centre and the market still meets on the cobbles of the old Market Square four days a week. Nestle and Hazell
column3: Watson and Viney and US automotive parts producer TRW have gone – the last left the town in 2006. However three major industrial and commercial centres make sure the town has one of the lowest unemployment rates in the country.A £150 million Arla Foods 'megadairy' opened just off the A41 in nearby Aston Clinton in November 2013
column4: roughly 3 1⁄2 mi (6 km) from the town centre and is a major employer in the area. Traffic improvement measures were paid for by Arla in order to reduce the impact of congestion and pollution.

column1: Aylesbury has two local semi-professional football teams
column2: Aylesbury Vale Dynamos F.C. which plays at Haywood Way and Aylesbury United F.C. which currently shares a ground with Chesham United. There is a strong cricket club in the town
column3: that was formed in 1837 with success in the 1950s and 1980s and is again emerging as one of the strong clubs in mid- to north Buckinghamshire. Since 2013
column4: Aylesbury has been host to a free 5 km run called the Aylesbury Parkrun.

column1: Aylesbury is represented in Rugby Union by Aylesbury Rugby Football Club
column2: situated at Ostler's Field in the nearby village of Weston Turville. It is widely considered Aylesbury's most successful sports team; 'The Ducks' play in the 7th tier of English Rugby.

column1: RailThe town is served by Aylesbury railway station and Aylesbury Vale Parkway railway station; the latter is terminus of passenger services of the London to Aylesbury Line from London Marylebone. Stoke Mandeville also lies in the town's urban area.

column2: in 1839 when the Aylesbury Railway opened from Cheddington on Robert Stephenson's London and Birmingham Railway. The Wycombe Railway (later Great Western Railway) arrived via Princes Risborough on 1 October 1863
column3: and on 23 September 1868 the Aylesbury and Buckingham Railway (later Metropolitan Railway) was opened from Verney Junction to almost connect a loop with the Wycombe Railway. The Metropolitan Railway (MetR) from Baker Street arrived via Amersham in 1892. The Great Central Railway (GCR) connected from Nottingham Victoria to London Marylebone via the MetR in 1899. Between 1899 and 1953
column4: Aylesbury had railway links to four London termini: Marylebone
column5: Baker Street
column6: Paddington and Euston. The Aylesbury Railway closed in 1953
column8: which later became the Metropolitan line of the London Underground withdrew north of Aylesbury in 1936 and withdrew from the town in 1961. The GCR was dismantled north of Aylesbury in 1966. As a result
column9: there were no regular passenger services north of Aylesbury until the opening of Aylesbury Vale Parkway railway station in December 2008. Now only the GCR south of Aylesbury Vale Parkway to Marylebone is used for regular London services.

column1: A rail scheme to extend passenger services northwestwards to a new station
column2: Aylesbury Vale Parkway
column3: was completed in December 2008. This is sited on the formerly goods-only line towards Quainton at the point where the line crosses the A41 near Berryfields Farm on the north-west outskirts of the town
column4: some 2.25 miles (3.62 km) north of the main Aylesbury station. This area is to be known as Berryfields
column5: a major development area and will include park and ride facilities for Aylesbury.

column1: A further expansion of rail services to a new Winslow railway station
column2: Milton Keynes Central
column3: Bedford and Oxford via the Claydon LNE Junction (see East West Rail) is due to be opened by 2030.}

column1: RoadsAylesbury is served by the A41 from London to Birkenhead
column2: which becomes the M40 however at Bicester 13 miles (21 km) west (by north) of Aylesbury. The A413 and A418 roads also run through the town. The M40 motorway at junction 9 is 14.7 miles (23.7 km) away and the M25 motorway is just over 21 miles (34 km)'s drive.
work commenced on the public transport hub
column3: a scheme comprising a one-way loop of bus lanes around the town's inner ring road
column4: which includes improvements to the connectivity between bus and rail services. The first two phases of this scheme were completed in 2007
column5: providing new bus lanes on Exchange Street
column6: New Street
column8: and also opened up High Street to buses. The final two phases
column9: including the Bourg Walk Bridge and Station Boulevard were officially opened in April 2009.Aylesbury is well connected to local destinations by bus services. Run by Arriva Shires & Essex
column10: these services run every 20–30 minutes to Milton Keynes (150)
column15: Hemel Hempstead (500) and Watford (500). Hourly services also run to Luton (61) and Leighton Buzzard (150/164). Arriva also runs services to RAF Halton via Weston Turville and Wendover (50); Chesham via Wendover
column16: Great Missenden and Amersham (55); Steeple Claydon via Waddesdon and Quainton (with some services to Twyford and Marsh Gibbon) (16); Thame via Cuddington
column17: Long Crendon and Worminghall (110); Buckingham and Maids Moreton via Whitchurch

column1: Scenes from the film A Clockwork Orange were filmed in Friars Square in Aylesbury but did not make it to the final cut. This is the 'Librarian Scene' where outtakes from the shoot and rehearsal can be seen in Alison Castle's The Stanley Kubrick Archives published by Taschen. The opening scene when the droogs beat up an elderly Irishman is mistakenly cited as being filmed in the underpass linking Friars Square Shopping Centre with the railway station. Although Christiane Kubrick's book Stanley Kubrick – A Life in Pictures states this the underpass in the film has a different shape to the one in Aylesbury and these sequences were actually filmed in Wandsworth.The County Court building and Aylesbury Market Square regularly feature in the BBC Television series Judge John Deed.
Aylesbury is twinned with the French town of Bourg-en-Bresse
